Do you listen to audiobooks? What are the benefits, in your opinion, of listening instead of reading? Are there advantages to reading that cannot be gained by listening? Which method do you prefer? Why?

---

I don't listen to audiobooks. I don't have a problem with them, but I just prefer reading. I think it's because I'm a very visual person. I like to see the words on the page, and I like to see how they look when I read them aloud. I like to see the punctuation and the spacing.
I think it's also because I'm a very fast reader.
 I can read a book in a day or two, and I don't think I could listen to an audiobook that quickly. I think I would get impatient and want to speed it up. 
I also like the fact that I can read a book in any order.
 I can read it in the order it was written, or I can skip around and read the chapters in any order I want. I can even skip around within chapters. I can read the first paragraph of a chapter, then skip to the last paragraph, then go back to the beginning.

I don't listen to audiobooks. I don't have a problem with them, but I just prefer reading. I think it's because I'm a very visual person. I like to see the words on the page, and I like to see how they look when I read them aloud. I like to see the punctuation and the spacing.

 I can read it in the order it was written, or I can skip around and read the chapters in any order I want. I can even skip around within chapters. I can read the first paragraph of a chapter, then skip to the last paragraph, then go back to the beginning.

Hardcover books don't hurt my ears, and I don't have to worry about recharging my batteries. I already have enough electronic items, that I don't need anything else to get a virus, glitch, or need charging

 think the only advantage to listening to an audiobook is that you can do other things while you're listening.

I think it's also because I'm a very fast reader.
 I can read a book in a day or two, and I don't think I could listen to an audiobook that quickly. I think I would get impatient and want to speed it up. 
I also like the fact that I can read a book in any order.
 I can read it in the order it was written, or I can skip around and read the chapters in any order I want. I can even skip around within chapters. I can read the first paragraph of a chapter, then skip to the last paragraph, then go back to the beginning.

Hardcover books don't hurt my ears, and I don't have to worry about recharging my batteries. I already have enough electronic items, that I don't need anything else to get a virus, glitch, or need charging. 

 think the only advantage to listening to an audiobook is that you can do other things while you're listening.
 You can walk, drive, or do housework while you're listening. You can't do that with a book.

 I can read it in the order it was written, or I can skip around and read the chapters in any order I want. I can even skip around within chapters. I can read the first paragraph of a chapter, then skip to the last paragraph, then go back to the beginning.

Hardcover books don't hurt my ears, and I don't have to worry about recharging my batteries. I already have enough electronic items, that I don't need anything else to get a virus, glitch, or need charging. 

 think the only advantage to listening to an audiobook is that you can do other things while you're listening.
 You can walk, drive, or do housework while you're listening. You can't do that with a book.

I also like the fact that I can read a book in any order.
 I can read it in the order it was written, or I can skip around and read the chapters in any order I want. I can even skip around within chapters. I can read the first paragraph of a chapter, then skip to the last paragraph, then go back to the beginning.

Hardcover books don't hurt my ears, and I don't have to worry about recharging my batteries. I already have enough electronic items, that I don't need anything else to get a virus, glitch, or need charging. 

 think the only advantage to listening to an audiobook is that you can do other things while you're listening.
 You can walk, drive, or do housework while you're listening. You can't do that with a book.

I don't listen to audiobooks. I don't have a problem with them, but I just prefer reading. I think it's because I'm a very visual person. I like to see the words on the page, and I like to see how they look when I read them aloud. I like to see the punctuation and the spacing.
I think it's also because I'm a very fast reader.
 I can read a book in a day or two, and I don't think I could listen to an audiobook that quickly. I think I would get impatient and want to speed it up. 
I also like the fact that I can read a book in any order.
 I can read it in the order it was written, or I can skip around and read the chapters in any order I want. I can even skip around within chapters. I can read the first paragraph of a chapter, then skip to the last paragraph, then go back to the beginning.

Hardcover books don't hurt my ears, and I don't have to worry about recharging my batteries. I already have enough electronic items, that I don't need anything else to get a virus, glitch, or need charging. 

 think the only advantage to listening to an audiobook is that you can do other things while you're listening.
 You can walk, drive, or do housework while you're listening. You can't do that with a book.

I don't listen to audiobooks. I don't have a problem with them, but I just prefer reading. I think it's because I'm a very visual person. I like to see the words on the page, and I like to see how they look when I read them aloud. I like to see the punctuation and the spacing.
I think it's also because I'm a very fast reader.
 I can read a book in a day or two, and I don't think I could listen to an audiobook that quickly. I think I would get impatient and want to speed it up. 
I also like the fact that I can read a book in any order.
 I can read it in the order it was written, or I can skip around and read the chapters in any order I want. I can even skip around within chapters. I can read the first paragraph of a chapter, then skip to the last paragraph, then go back to the beginning.

Hardcover books don't hurt my ears, and I don't have to worry about recharging my batteries. I already have enough electronic items, that I don't need anything else to get a virus, glitch, or need charging. 

 think the only advantage to listening to an audiobook is that you can do other things while you're listening.
 You can walk, drive, or do housework while you're listening. You can't do that with a book.

I can recognize why people would listen to audiobooks, but they're not for me. I prefer a book in my hand, and t

I don't listen to audiobooks. I don't have a problem with them, but I just prefer reading. I think it's because I'm a very visual person. I like to see the words on the page, and I like to see how they look when I read them aloud. I like to see the punctuation and the spacing.
I think it's also because I'm a very fast reader.
 I can read a book in a day or two, and I don't think I could listen to an audiobook that quickly. I think I would get impatient and want to speed it up. 
I also like the fact that I can read a book in any order.
 I can read it in the order it was written, or I can skip around and read the chapters in any order I want. I can even skip around within chapters. I can read the first paragraph of a chapter, then skip to the last paragraph, then go back to the beginning.

Hardcover books don't hurt my ears, and I don't have to worry about recharging my batteries. I already have enough electronic items, that I don't need anything else to get a virus, glitch, or need charging. 

 think the only advantage to listening to an audiobook is that you can do other things while you're listening.
 You can walk, drive, or do housework while you're listening. You can't do that with a book.

I can recognize why people would listen to audiobooks, but they're not for me. I prefer a book in my hand, and the freedom to ctronl

I don't listen to audiobooks. I don't have a problem with them, but I just prefer reading. I think it's because I'm a very visual person. I like to see the words on the page, and I like to see how they look when I read them aloud. I like to see the punctuation and the spacing.

 I can read a book in a day or two, and I don't think I could listen to an audiobook that quickly. I think I would get impatient and want to speed it up. 
I also like the fact that I can read a book in any order.
 I can read it in the order it was written, or I can skip around and read the chapters in any order I want. I can even skip around within chapters. I can read the first paragraph of a chapter, then skip to the last paragraph, then go back to the beginning.

Hardcover books don't hurt my ears, and I don't have to worry about an apathetic, sle or nasal narrator. I already have enough electronic items, that I don't need anything else to get a virus, glitch, or need charging. 

 think the only advantage to listening to an audiobook is that you can do other things while you're listening.
 You can walk, drive, or do housework while you're listening. You can't do that with a book.

I can recognize why people would listen to audiobooks, but they're not for me. I prefer a book in my hand, and the freedom to control the

 You can walk, drive, or do housework while you're listening. You can't do that with a book.

I can recognize why people would listen to audiobooks, and why they're not for me. I prefer a book in my hand, and the freedom to control the pace!

Is Listening to a Book Just as Good as Reading It?

I don't listen to audiobooks. I don't have a problem with them, but I just prefer reading. I think it's because I'm a very visual person. I like to see the words on the page, and I like to see how they look when I read them aloud. I like to see the punctuation and the spacing.

I don't listen to audiobooks. I don't have a problem with them, but I just prefer reading. I think it's because I'm a very visual person. I like to see the words on the page, and I like to see how they look when I read them aloud. I like to see the punctuation and the spacing.
I think it's also because I'm a very fast reader.
 I can read a book in a day or two, and I don't think I could listen to an audiobook that quickly. I think I would get impatient and want to speed it up. 
I also like the fact that I can read a book in any order.
 I can read it in the order it was written, or I can skip around and read the chapters in any order I want. I can even skip around within chapters. I can read the first paragraph of a chapter, then skip to the last paragraph, then go back to the beginning if I have question

Hardcover books don't hurt my ears, and I don't have to worry about an apathetic, sleepy, or nasal narrator. I already have enough electronic items, that I don't need anything else to get a virus, glitch, or need charging. 

 think the only advantage to listening to an audiobook is that you can do other things while you're listening.
 You can walk, drive, or do housework while you're listening. You can't do that with a book.

I can recognize why people would listen to audiobooks, and why they're not for me. I prefer a book in my hand, and the freedom to control the pace!

 I can read a book in a day or two, and I don't think I could listen to an audiobook that quickly. I think I would get impatient and want to speed it up. 
I also like the fact that I can read a book in any order.
 I can read it in the order it was written, or I can skip around and read the chapters in any order I want. I can even skip around within chapters. I can read the first paragraph of a chapter, then skip to the last paragraph, then go back to the beginning if I have questions. Reading a hardcov

Hardcover books don't hurt my ears, and I don't have to worry about an apathetic, sleepy, or nasal narrator. I already have enough electronic items, that I don't need anything else to get a virus, glitch, or need charging. 

 think the only advantage to listening to an audiobook is that you can do other things while you're listening.
 You can walk, drive, or do housework while you're listening. You can't do that with a book.

I can recognize why people would listen to audiobooks, and why they're not for me. I prefer a book in my hand, and the freedom to control the pace!

Is Listening to a Book Just as Good as Reading It?

Do you listen to audiobooks? What are the benefits, in your opinion, of listening instead of reading? Are there advantages to reading that cannot be gained by listening? Which method do you prefer? Why?

 I can read a book in a day or two, and I don't think I could listen to an audiobook that quickly. I think I would get impatient and want to speed it up. 
I also like the fact that I can read a book in any order.
 I can read it in the order it was written, or I can skip around and read the chapters in any order I want. I can even skip around within chapters. I can read the first paragraph of a chapter, then skip to the last paragraph, then go back to the beginning if I have questions. Reading a real boo

Hardcover books don't hurt my ears, and I don't have to worry about an apathetic, sleepy, or nasal narrator. I already have enough electronic items, that I don't need anything else to get a virus, glitch, or need charging. 

 think the only advantage to listening to an audiobook is that you can do other things while you're listening.
 You can walk, drive, or do housework while you're listening. You can't do that with a book.

I can recognize why people would listen to audiobooks, and why they're not for me. I prefer a book in my hand, and the freedom to control the pace!

Is Listening to a Book Just as Good as Reading It?

I don't listen to audiobooks. I don't have a problem with them, but I just prefer reading. I think it's because I'm a very visual person. I like to see the words on the page, and I like to see how they look when I read them aloud. I like to see the punctuation and the spacing.
I think it's also because I'm a very fast reader.
 I can read a book in a day or two, and I don't think I could listen to an audiobook that quickly. I think I would get impatient and want to speed it up. 
I also like the fact that I can read a book in any order.
 I can read it in the order it was written, or I can skip around and read the chapters in any order I want. I can even skip around within chapters. I can read the first paragraph of a chapter, then skip to the last paragraph, then go back to the beginning if I have questions. Reading a real book appeals to my ADH

Hardcover books don't hurt my ears, and I don't have to worry about an apathetic, sleepy, or nasal narrator. I already have enough electronic items, that I don't need anything else to get a virus, glitch, or need charging. 

 think the only advantage to listening to an audiobook is that you can do other things while you're listening.
 You can walk, drive, or do housework while you're listening. You can't do that with a book.

I can recognize why people would listen to audiobooks, and why they're not for me. I prefer a book in my hand, and the freedom to control the pace!

I don't listen to audiobooks. I don't have a problem with them, but I just prefer reading. I think it's because I'm a very visual person. I like to see the words on the page, and I like to see how they look when I read them aloud. I like to see the ill.
I think it's also because I'm a very fast reader.
 I can read a book in a day or two, and I don't think I could listen to an audiobook that quickly. I think I would get impatient and want to speed it up. 
I also like the fact that I can read a book in any order.
 I can read it in the order it was written, or I can skip around and read the chapters in any order I want. I can even skip around within chapters. I can read the first paragraph of a chapter, then skip to the last paragraph, then go back to the beginning if I have questions. Reading a real book appeals to my ADHD. 

Hardcover books don't hurt my ears, and I don't have to worry about an apathetic, sleepy, or nasal narrator. I already have enough electronic items, that I don't need anything else to get a virus, glitch, screen crack, or need charging.

Hardcover books don't hurt my ears, and I don't have to worry about an apathetic, sleepy, or nasal narrator. I already have enough electronic items, that I don't need anything else to get a virus, glitch, screen crack, or need charging. 

 think the only advantage to listening to an audiobook is that you can do other things while you're listening.
 You can walk, drive, or do housework while you're listening. You can't do that with a book.

I can recognize why people would listen to audiobooks, and why they're not for me. I prefer a book in my hand, and the freedom to control the pace!

Is Listening to a Book Just as Good as Reading It?

I don't listen to audiobooks. I don't have a problem with them, but I just prefer reading. I think it's because I'm a very visual person. I like to see the words on the page, and I like to see how they look when I read them aloud. I like to see the illustrations, diagrams, and author's .
I think it's also because I'm a very fast reader.
 I can read a book in a day or two, and I don't think I could listen to an audiobook that quickly. I think I would get impatient and want to speed it up. 
I also like the fact that I can read a book in any order.
 I can read it in the order it was written, or I can skip around and read the chapters in any order I want. I can even skip around within chapters. I can read the first paragraph of a chapter, then skip to the last paragraph, then go back to the beginning if I have questions. Reading a real book appeals to my ADHD. 

Hardcover books don't hurt my ears, and I don't have to worry about an apathetic, sleepy, or nasal narrator. I already have enough electronic items, that I don't need anything else to get a virus, glitch, screen crack, or need charging. 

 think the only advantage to listening to an audiobook is that you can do other things while you're listening.
 You can walk, drive, or do housework while you're listening. You can't do that with a book.

I can recognize why people would listen to audiobooks, and why they're not for me. I prefer a book in my hand, and the freedom to control the pace!

Hardcover books don't hurt my ears, and I don't have to worry about an apathetic, sleepy, or nasal narrator. I already have enough electronic items, that I don't need anything else to get a virus, glitch, screen crack, or need charging. 

 think the only advantage to listening to an audiobook is that you can do other things while you're listening.
 You can walk, drive, or do housework while you're listening. You can't do that with a book.

I can recognize why people would listen to audiobooks, and why they're not for me. I prefer a book in my hand, and the freedom to control the pace!

I like to see the words on the page, and I like to see how they look when I read them aloud. I like to see the illustrations, diagrams, and author's notes. I can skip to the back 
I think it's also because I'm a very fast reader.
 I can read a book in a day or two, and I don't think I could listen to an audiobook that quickly. I think I would get impatient and want to speed it up. 
I also like the fact that I can read a book in any order.
 I can read it in the order it was written, or I can skip around and read the chapters in any order I want. I can even skip around within chapters. I can read the first paragraph of a chapter, then skip to the last paragraph, then go back to the beginning if I have questions. Reading a real book appeals to my ADHD.

I don't listen to audiobooks. I don't have a problem with them, but I just prefer reading. I think it's because I'm a very visual person. I like to see the words on the page, and I like to see how they look when I read them aloud. I like to see the illustrations, diagrams, and author's notes. I can skip to the back for a quick timeli
I think it's also because I'm a very fast reader.
 I can read a book in a day or two, and I don't think I could listen to an audiobook that quickly. I think I would get impatient and want to speed it up. 
I also like the fact that I can read a book in any order.
 I can read it in the order it was written, or I can skip around and read the chapters in any order I want. I can even skip around within chapters. I can read the first paragraph of a chapter, then skip to the last paragraph, then go back to the beginning if I have questions. Reading a real book appeals to my ADHD. 

Hardcover books don't hurt my ears, and I don't have to worry about an apathetic, sleepy, or nasal narrator. I already have enough electronic items, that I don't need anything else to get a virus, glitch, screen crack, or need charging. 

 think the only advantage to listening to an audiobook is that you can do other things while you're listening.
 You can walk, drive, or do housework while you're listening. You can't do that with a book.

I can recognize why people would listen to audiobooks, and why they're not for me. I prefer a book in my hand, and the freedom to control the pace!

I can recognize why people would listen to audiobooks, and why they're not for me. I prefer a book in my hand, and the freedom to control the pace!

Is Listening to a Book Just as Good as Reading It?

Do you listen to audiobooks? What are the benefits, in your opinion, of listening instead of reading? Are there advantages to reading that cannot be gained by listening? Which method do you prefer? Why?

I don't listen to audiobooks. I don't have a problem with them, but I just prefer reading. I think it's because I'm a very visual person. I like to see the words on the page, and I like to see how they look when I read them aloud. I like to see the illustrations, diagrams, and author's notes. I can skip to the back for a quick timeline or geneology.
I think it's also because I'm a very fast reader.
 I can read a book in a day or two, and I don't think I could listen to an audiobook that quickly. I think I would get impatient and want to speed it up. 
I also like the fact that I can read a book in any order.
 I can read it in the order it was written, or I can skip around and read the chapters in any order I want. I can even skip around within chapters. I can read the first paragraph of a chapter, then skip to the last paragraph, then go back to the beginning if I have questions. Reading a real book appeals to my ADHD. 

Hardcover books don't hurt my ears, and I don't have to worry about an apathetic, sleepy, or nasal narrator. I already have enough electronic items, that I don't need anything else to get a virus, glitch, screen crack, or need charging. 

 think the only advantage to listening to an audiobook is that you can do other things while you're listening.
 You can walk, drive, or do housework while you're listening. You can't do that with a book.

I can recognize why people would listen to audiobooks, and why they're not for me. I prefer a book in my hand, and the freedom to control the pace!

Hardcover books don't hurt my ears, and I don't have to worry about an apathetic, sleepy, or nasal narrator. I already have enough electronic items, that I don't need anything else to get a virus, glitch, screen crack, or need charging. 

 think the only advantage to listening to an audiobook is that you can do other things while you're listening.
 You can walk, drive, or do housework while you're listening. You can't do that with a book.

I can recognize why people would listen to audiobooks, and why they're not for me. I prefer a book in my hand, and the freedom to control the pace!

Is Listening to a Book Just as Good as Reading It?

Do you listen to audiobooks? What are the benefits, in your opinion, of listening instead of reading? Are there advantages to reading that cannot be gained by listening? Which method do you prefer? Why?

I don't listen to audiobooks. I don't have a problem with them, but I just prefer reading. I think it's because I'm a very visual person. I like to see the words on the page, and I like to see how they look when I read them aloud. I like to see the illustrations, diagrams, and author's notes. I can skip to the back for a quick timeline or genealogy. 
I think it's also because I'm a very fast reader.
 I can read a book in a day or two, and I don't think I could listen to an audiobook that quickly. I think I would get impatient and want to speed it up.
